title: ‘I’m Here! Can You Hear Me?’: One Family’s Story of Death in Gaza
abstract: The Abu Teirs thought the Israel-Hamas cease-fire might mean they could start to rebuild their lives. But a new round of Israeli airstrikes dashed those dreams.
byline: By Vivian Yee and Bilal Shbair

abstract: The announcement suggests that Israel is shifting tactics to hold on to swaths of the territory, at least temporarily.

title: Why Was This the Only High-Rise in Bangkok to Topple After the Quake?
abstract: Workers said poor-quality materials were used during construction by a Chinese developer as it sought to cut costs. Investigators also said they found substandard steel bars in the rubble.
byline: By Damien Cave and Muktita Suhartono

title: Angola Rail Line Offers Clues to Trump’s Africa Policy
abstract: The $4 billion project was the Biden administration’s signature initiative in Africa. Early signs are that the Trump team supports it, too, for mineral access if nothing else.

abstract: The ruling junta has vowed to continue military operations that include airstrikes against rebel groups, even as aid organizations struggle to reach devastated areas.

title: Death Sentences Commuted for 3 Americans Over Failed Congo Coup
abstract: The three Americans had their sentences reduced to life imprisonment ahead of an expected visit from a Trump official.

title: China’s New Barges Could Make a Tough Task Easier: Invading Taiwan
abstract: The barges, which link up to form a bridge, could give China a way to land large numbers of vehicles and troops on Taiwan, solving a major logistical problem.
byline: By Chris Buckley, Christoph Koettl and Agnes Chang

title: 23 More Women Come Forward With Allegations Against Serial Rapist
abstract: Zou Zhenhao was convicted in London of raping 10 women in Britain, where he was a student, and in China.

multimedia.caption: A photo made available by the London police of an apartment used by Zou Zhenhao. The court heard he would lure women to his apartments, drug them and rape them.
A photo made available by the London police of an apartment used by Zou Zhenhao. The court heard he would lure women to his apartments, drug them and rape them.

title: Heathrow Was Warned of Power Supply Vulnerabilities, Airlines Advocate Says
abstract: The official said he had raised concerns about Heathrow’s electricity supply days before a power outage forced it to shut down. Heathrow disputed the relevance of the official’s comments.
byline: By Amelia Nierenberg and Michael D. Shear

multimedia.caption: Firefighters dousing flames at an electrical substation, about a mile from Heathrow, that caught fire last month. The blaze cut off power to the airport for almost an entire day.
Firefighters dousing flames at an electrical substation, about a mile from Heathrow, that caught fire last month. The blaze cut off power to the airport for almost an entire day.

title: A Family Business Empire, and a Culture of ‘Keeping Your Mouth Shut’
abstract: The Irving family businesses dominate Saint John, New Brunswick. They are a major employer, but residents say those jobs have come with a steep cost.
byline: By Chris Donovan and Ian Austen

title: France Moves Closer to Adding a Missing Word to Its Rape Law: Consent
abstract: After dozens of men were convicted of raping a drugged Gisèle Pelicot, lawmakers moved to require that consent be given for sex to be considered consensual.
byline: By Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic

title: These Militias Refuse to Join Syria’s New Army
abstract: The militias that control the Druse religious minority’s heartland in southwestern Syria have resisted the new government’s attempts to bring all armed groups under its control.
byline: By Christina Goldbaum, Reham Mourshed and David Guttenfelder

title: A Prison Death Highlights an L.G.B.T.Q. Crackdown in Russia
abstract: The Russian government has unleashed a wave of repression against L.G.B.T.Q. people, with the police raiding gay night clubs and investigators targeting people they suspect of being gay.
byline: By Nataliya Vasilyeva and Alina Lobzina

abstract: The United Nations said Israeli forces killed the people as they were trying to aid injured civilians, then buried them in a mass grave. Israel said nine of the 15 dead were Palestinian militants.

abstract: Chun Wang, a Chinese-born crypto entrepreneur, paid an undisclosed amount for the mission. Some satellites are already in polar orbit, and researchers called it a routine flight.

abstract: The eruption began near Grindavik, a small town long threatened by volcanic disruptions, and prompted the closure of a popular tourist destination.
byline: By Amelia Nierenberg and Egill Bjarnason
